quiz.title: Our Solar System
quiz.introText: Welcome to the Solar System Quiz! This quiz is designed for school kids who want to learn about our Solar System. You will be presented with SOME questions related to the Solar System, and each question will have multiple options to choose from. Choose the correct option to score points and increase your knowledge about our Solar System. Let's get started!

questions.content: Which planet in our Solar System is known as the 'Red Planet'?
questions.explanation: Mars is known as the 'Red Planet' due to its reddish appearance in the night sky. The color is due to iron oxide or rust on its surface.

questions.content: Which planet in our Solar System is the largest?
questions.explanation: Jupiter is the largest planet in our Solar System, with a diameter of 86,881 miles (139,822 kilometers). Its mass is more than twice the combined mass of all the other planets in our Solar System.

questions.content: Which planet in our Solar System has the most moons?
questions.explanation: Jupiter has the most moons of any planet in our Solar System, with 79 confirmed moons and possibly more yet to be discovered. The four largest moons of Jupiter are known as the Galilean moons and were discovered by Galileo Galilei in 1610.

questions.content: Which planet in our Solar System has the shortest day?
questions.explanation: Jupiter has the shortest day of any planet in our Solar System, with a day length of only 9 hours and 56 minutes. This is due to its rapid rotation, which is the fastest of any planet in our Solar System.

questions.content: What is the name of the largest moon in our Solar System?
questions.explanation: Ganymede is the largest moon in our Solar System, and is larger than the planet Mercury. It orbits Jupiter and was discovered by Galileo Galilei in 1610.

questions.content: What is the largest volcano in our Solar System?
questions.explanation: Olympus Mons is the largest volcano in our Solar System, and is located on the planet Mars. It is about 13.6 miles (22 kilometers) high, which is almost three times the height of Mount Everest.
